label: media

text: UN figures indicate that 80% of people displaced by climate change are women
label: media

text: Roles as primary caregivers and providers of food and fuel make them more vulnerable when flooding and drought occur
label: media

text: The 2015 Paris Agreement has made specific provision for the empowerment of women, recognising that they are disproportionately impacted
label: media

text: Getty Images Millions in Nigeria, Cameroon, Chad, Niger and the Central African Republic rely on Lake Chad In central Africa, where up to 90% of Lake Chad has disappeared , nomadic indigenous groups are particularly at risk
label: media

text: As the lake's shoreline recedes, women have to walk much further to collect water
label: media

text: "In the dry season, men go to the towns
label: media

text: leaving women to look after the community," explains Hindou Oumarou Ibrahim, coordinator of the Association of Indigenous Women and People of Chad (AFPAT)
label: media

text: With dry seasons now becoming longer, women are working harder to feed and care for their families without support
label: media

text: "They become more vulnerable
label: media

text: it's very hard work," Ibrahim recently told the 's 100 Women initiative

label: media

label: media

text: com/five-ways-that-climate-change-threatens-human-health-242711 Link copied Share article As the UN’s climate summit, Cop29 , gets underway in Azerbaijan this week, the effect of climate change on human health is high on the agenda
label: media

text: And rightly so, amid some alarming emerging statistics
label: media

text: By the end of this century, climate change could be the cause of more than 3 million deaths per year (around five times as many annual deaths globally of HIV and Aids)
label: media

text: A new report from a scientific review committee of experts called the Lancet Countdown highlights how globally people are facing “record-breaking threats” to their health as a consequence of climate change
label: media

text: The major climate risks include negative effects on food security (including production), spread of diseases, ecosystems, infrastructure and the economy
label: media

text: Despite having contributed the least to global emissions, Africa will be most affected by climate change
label: media

text: This is due to the fragile economics and exposure to extreme weather events across much of the continent
label: media

text: But all continents, including Europe , will be negatively affected
label: media

text: Everyone working in health needs to prepare for and be equipped to respond to the health consequences of the climate crisis
label: media

text: The Lancet highlights the opportunity “to redefine the social and environmental determinants of health”
label: media

text: These are the top five priorities when it comes to climate change and human health: 1
label: media

text: New and emerging infectious diseases Drastic environmental change increases the risk of catching deadly infectious diseases such as malaria, dengue and West Nile virus in new areas
label: media

text: Modelling shows that mosquito populations could move into different regions of Africa and South America, and into Europe
label: media

text: The parasitic ticks that transmit the Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever virus may move north from Africa into Europe as climate change takes hold
label: media

text: The threat of outbreaks of new and emerging infections, and pandemics, is increasing
label: media

text: In 2022, the World Health Organization warned that Ebola outbreaks around Africa are becoming more frequent due to climate change, as bats – the likely source of the virus – migrate and seek new habitats to breed
label: media

text: Infectious diseases are predicted to spread more easily due to climate change, and thus increase the risk of pandemics
label: media

text: This threat includes Lassa fever, a virus thought to be transmitted by rats
label: media

text: Modelling has indicated that the rats may flee fire and flood, find new habitats and thus expose greater numbers of humans to new or different viruses
label: media

text: Food security and nutrition Climate change exacerbates food insecurity
label: media

text: In Ghana, West Africa, inconsistent rainfall during the 2024 rainy season has left an estimated 1
label: media

text: 05 million people acutely food insecure
label: media

text: This is the case particularly in the north of the country, an area already with a high level of food insecurity and hunger
label: media

text: The UN predicts that more than 600 million people will be living in hunger by 2030, due to the impact of climate shocks and lack of aid and government action thus far
label: media

text: Climate change worsens food insecurity from many different angles; from rural farmers in Ghana losing their crops due to unexpected changes in rainfall, to the impact of affordability of imports in the UK, there won’t be just hunger hotspots
label: media

text: As food insecurity deteriorates, so will malnutrition globally
label: media

text: By 2030, between 570,000 and 1 million children under five years old will suffer from stunted growth due to climate change, also exacerbating their vulnerability to infectious diseases such as malaria
label: media

text: Access to healthcare Extreme weather can physically prevent people from accessing healthcare
label: media

text: Between 2014 and 2023, 61% of land globally experienced an increase in the number of days of extreme rainfall, compared to 1961-1990
label: media

text: Flash floods have devastated Valencia in Spain, with health services anticipating increases in diarrhoea, skin infections and hepatitis A
label: media

text: Evidence from Ghana shows that physical access to healthcare is restricted, with patients and sometimes health workers unable to reach local health centres, and emergency referrals unable to reach hospitals
label: media

text: Access to healthcare provision becomes harder during extreme weather conditions
label: media

text: Riccardo Mayer/Shutterstock The Lancet report also found that only two-thirds of countries had high or very high implementation of legally required health emergency plans
label: media

text: This number needs to be 100% to protect population health as extreme weather events become more frequent, unpredictable and severe
label: media

text: Delays to reduce carbon emissions and attempt to rectify the situation are only adding to the issue
label: media

text: Global energy-related carbon emissions reached a new high in 2023, showing little signs of slowing down
label: media

text: In a 2023 study conducted in Mion (northern Ghana), nearly all participants reported not being able to access a healthcare facility when they needed to at least once, due to climatic conditions
label: media

text: Similarly, in the Volta region in Ghana, many residents lost all their belongings during unexpected flooding in 2023 including health insurance documents
label: media

text: This means people cannot access vital medications or services such as insulin if diabetic, or emergency care
label: media

text: Air quality Air quality is one of the most locally-felt impacts of climate change, especially in heavily industrialised countries
label: media

text: The UK Health Security Agency estimates that around 36,000 deaths annually are attributable to air pollution in the UK, with this number jumping to 2 million in China
label: media

text: This is in part due to causing new, or exacerbating existing, chronic respiratory conditions such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which one in five people suffer with in the UK
label: media

text: It also reduces life expectancy through prolonged exposure, causing diseases such as coronary heart disease and lung cancer
label: media

text: Extreme heat In 2023, increased heat exposure put those engaged in outdoor physical activity (which includes everything from agricultural labour to recreational running) at risk of heat stress for 28% more hours than two decades ago
label: media

text: Heat stress has been associated with debilitating issues such as kidney stones, exhaustion, asthma and heart attacks
label: media

text: Any amount of activity or movement in rising temperatures will put individuals at great risk of these conditions
label: media

text: This will compromise income if labour is based outdoors, population health if we can do less outside, and the ability to enjoy the outdoor world
label: media

text: Don’t have time to read about climate change as much as you’d like
label: media

text: Get a weekly roundup in your inbox instead
label: media

text: Every Wednesday, The Conversation’s environment editor writes Imagine, a short email that goes a little deeper into just one climate issue
label: media

text: "How to live forever Skip to content Home News Sport Business Innovation Culture Arts Travel Earth Audio Video Live Home News Sport Business Innovation Culture Arts Travel Earth Audio Video Live Weather Newsletters How to live forever 21 April 2014 Share Save Frank Swain Features correspondent Share Save (Thinkstock) If more and more people are living past 100, how much older can we survive to, in theory, asks Frank Swain
label: media

text: And what would it take to achieve this in practice
label: media

text: On the Art of Prolonging Life was penned by a Dr Huseland (“one of the soundest minds in Germany”) in 1797, concluding eight years of study on the topic
label: media

text: He identified among the many factors associated with long life: a moderate diet that was rich in vegetables and short on meat and sweetened pastries; an active lifestyle; good care of your teeth; weekly bathing in lukewarm water with soap; good sleep; clean air; and being born to parents who themselves lived long lives
label: media

text: Toward the end of his essay, translated for the American Review, the doctor wistfully speculated that “human life may be prolonged to double the extent of what is supposed to be its present limits, without losing activity and usefulness
label: media

text: ” By Huseland’s estimates, half of all children born would die before their tenth birthday, an alarmingly high mortality rate
label: media

text: However, if the child could run the gauntlet of youth fraught with smallpox, measles, rubella, and other childhood diseases, they stood a fair chance of making it all the way to their mid-thirties
label: media

text: In ideal circumstances, Huseland thought it possible that a lifetime could stretch for two hundred years
label: media

text: Is there more to these claims than the fanciful imagination of an 18th century doctor
label: media

text: James Vaupel doesn’t think it’s out of the question
label: media

text: “Life expectancy is increasing two-and-a-half years every decade,” he says
label: media

text: “That’s twenty five years every century
label: media

text: ” As director of the Laboratory of Survival and Longevity at the Max Planck Institute for Demographic Research in Rostock, Germany, Vaupel studies longevity and survival in human and animal populations
label: media

text: He tells me that the pattern of improvements to mortality has shifted greatly in the past 100 years
label: media

text: Before 1950, most of the gains in life expectancy were made by combating the high infant mortality that Huseland noted
label: media

text: Since then, however, it’s been the over-60s and most recently the over-80s who’ve seen the greatest decreases in mortality
label: media

text: In other words, we are not just surviving childhood in greater numbers, we’re living longer – a lot longer
label: media

text: Age complex Worldwide, the number of centenarians – people over the age of 100 – is predicted to increase 10-fold between 2010 and 2050
label: media

text: As Huseland testified, a strong component in whether you’ll live to see this milestone lies in the age of your parents; that is, there is a genetic component to long life
label: media

text: But the rise in centenarians can’t be explained by genetics alone, which clearly haven’t changed much in the last couple of centuries
label: media

text: Rather, it’s a host of improvements to our lives that cumulatively improve our chances of living longer and stronger, many of which echo the factors identified by Huseland
label: media

text: The reasons include better healthcare, improving medical treatments, public health measures like cleaner water and air, better education, and improved standards of living such as houses that are warm and dry
label: media

text: “Mostly it’s down to having more medicine and money,” says Vaupel
label: media

text: Recent decades have seen significant improvements in life expectancy for the elderly (Thinkstock) Nonetheless, the gains offered by better healthcare and living conditions still leave many people dissatisfied, and the appetite for life-extension therapies shows no sign of abating
label: media

text: One popular approach is caloric restriction
label: media

text: In the 1930s, researchers noticed that mice fed on a near-starvation diet lived far longer than those allowed to eat until full
label: media

text: A subsequent study on rhesus monkeys also showed this, but this was contradicted by a 20-year-long study by the US National Institute on Ageing, which found that although rhesus monkeys kept on a calorie-restricted diet developed age-related diseases slightly later than controls, they did not live longer on average
label: media

text: The authors noted that though caloric restriction in long-lived animals conferred some benefits, these were subject to a complex interplay of genetics, nutrition and environmental factors
label: media

text: Another great hope is resveratrol, a chemical produced naturally by plants, notably in the skin of grapes
label: media

text: Whether vineyards can be said to hide the fountain of youth, however, remains doubtful
label: media

text: The chemical has been noted to produce similar health benefits to caloric restriction in animal models, but as yet, no study has shown that taking resveratrol can increase human lifespan
label: media

text: No limits But why do we age at all
label: media

text: “Every day we suffer damage and don’t perfectly repair it,” explains Vaupel, “and this accumulation of unrepaired damage is what causes age-related disease
label: media

text: ” It’s not a trait that is shared by all living organisms
label: media

text: Hydra for example – a group of simple, jellyfish-like creatures – are able to repair almost all the damage they suffer, and readily slough cells that are too injured to heal
label: media

text: In humans, it’s damaged cells like these that can give rise to cancerous tumours
label: media

text: “Hydras allocate resources primarily toward repair, rather than reproduction,” says Vaupel
label: media

text: “Humans, by contrast, primarily direct resources toward reproduction, it’s a different survival strategy at a species level
label: media

text: ” Humans may live fast and die young, but our prodigious fertility allows us to overcome these high mortality rates
label: media

text: Now that infant mortality is so low, there’s really no need to channel so many resources into reproduction, says Vaupel
label: media

text: “The trick is to up-regulate repair instead of diverting that energy into getting fat
label: media

text: In theory that should be possible, though nobody has any idea about how to do it
label: media

text: ” If the steady accretion of damage to our cells can be arrested – so-called negligible senescence – then perhaps we won’t have an upper age limit
label: media

text: If that’s the case, there isn’t any reason why we should have to die at all
label: media

text: Hydra can repair almost all its damaged cells, shedding any that are too injured to heal (Science Photo Library) “It would be wonderful to get to a world where all death is optional
label: media

text: Right now, essentially all of us are sentenced to the death penalty, even though most of us have done nothing to deserve it
label: media

text: ” So says Gennady Stolyarov, transhumanist philosopher and author of Death Is Wrong, a controversial children’s book that encourages young minds to reject the fatalist notion that death is inevitable
label: media

text: Stolyarov is fervently opposed to what he sees is simply a technological challenge waiting for the appropriate level of money and manpower to solve it
label: media

text: Agents of change One focus for technological intervention are telomeres
label: media

text: These caps on chromosomes shorten every time your cells divide, putting a hard limit on the number of times your cells can reproduce themselves
label: media

text: Not all animals experience this telomere shortening, the hydra being one of them
label: media

text: However, there are good reasons to have these limitations in place
label: media

text: Occasional mutations can allow cells to divide without shortening their telomeres, giving rise to “immortal” cell lines
label: media

text: However, in an uncontrolled situation, these immortal cells would be very bad news for the person they are in, bloating into cancerous tumours
label: media

text: “One hundred and fifty thousand people in the world die each day , two thirds of those die from causes related to senescence,” Stolyarov tells me
label: media

text: “So even if we can hasten the arrival of these technologies to achieve negligible senescence by one day, we will have saved a hundred thousand lives
label: media

text: ” The author quotes geronotology theoretician Aubrey de Grey – something of a celebrity in the world of life extension – as stating that there is a 50% chance of achieving negligible senescence in the next 25 years
label: media

text: “There’s a good chance that it will happen in our lifetimes, before we experience the most deleterious effects of senescence,” says Stolyarov
label: media

text: “Achieving negligible human senescence in 25 years is possible,” says Vaupel, “but highly unlikely
label: media

text: ” He concedes that it might be possible to rapidly accelerate life expectancy through medical breakthroughs
label: media

text: But he warns that equally, there may be difficulties in the future that we don’t anticipate
label: media

text: “Disease, economic crisis, and climate change might cause increases in mortality,” he says
label: media

text: Telomeres, the protective ends of chromosomes, are linked to ageing of cells (Science Photo Library) Stolyarov is hoping to kindle a small spark of hope into an eternal flame
label: media

text: “What I think is necessary right now is a determined push to dramatically accelerate the pace of technological progress,” he says
label: media

text: “We have a fighting chance right now, but in order to make it happen we have to be the agents of change
label: media

text: ” For now, readers will have to take comfort in the knowledge that there are well-documented ways to try to avoid the Western world’s two biggest killers – heart disease and cancer – through a combination of exercise, healthy eating, and moderation when it comes to alcohol and red meat
label: media

text: Very few of us actually manage to live by these criteria, perhaps because we think a shorter life filled with rich food and wine is a worthy trade
label: media

text: Which leads to the conundrum – if eternal life was possible, would you be willing to pay the price
label: media

text: com/why-we-need-to-talk-about-older-people-and-climate-change-in-africa-239107 Link copied Share article Africa is often viewed as a relatively young continent , with less than 7% of the population over 60
label: media

text: But this is set to change
label: media

text: Declining fertility rates and increasing life expectancy mean that by 2050, the number of people over 60 in Africa is projected to triple to 235 million (about 9% of the African population)
label: media

text: This demographic shift is occurring when global climate change is intensifying, leading to more frequent and severe extreme weather events such as heatwaves, flooding and tropical cyclones
label: media

text: By 2050, older adults in Africa are projected to face significantly higher heat exposure due to rapid population growth and climate change, with an increase in extreme heat events
label: media

text: This will heighten health risks and put pressure on local services, especially in low-income areas with limited ability to cope with the strain
label: media

text: As we age, it gets harder to control body temperature
label: media

text: Longtime health issues like heart and lung disease and diabetes make older people more likely to become dehydrated
label: media

text: In Africa, many older people struggle to get the physical, mental, social and financial support they need to cope with the direct and indirect effects of extreme weather
label: media

text: Urgent strategies are therefore needed to protect older people from extreme weather such as heatwaves
label: media

text: These include cooling infrastructure (air conditioning) and early warning systems that tell older people when it is getting dangerously hot
label: media

text: Climate change adaptation plans must be integrated with policies on ageing to protect older people
label: media

text: I research climate gerontology – the intersection between ageing and climate change
label: media

text: As part of my research I am undertaking a series of Global Ageing and Climate Change Regional Dialogues in collaboration with HelpAge International
label: media

text: Here are the key issues we found in Africa
label: media

text: Climate change is harsh on older people Older people vary in health and mobility
label: media

text: Some older individuals remain active and healthy, allowing them to cope better with the disruptions caused by extreme weather
label: media

text: Other, less active older adults tend to be vulnerable to climate-related threats because of weaker physical health, reduced mobility and higher risk of existing disease
label: media

text: Heat can be deadly for older people
label: media

text: Adam Kaz/Getty Images In Africa, older people are at greater risk because the continent has limited basic infrastructure
label: media

text: This is especially the case in rural areas, where access to healthcare, clean water and emergency services is often poor
label: media

text: Poverty, living alone, and depending on small-scale farming make them even more susceptible to extreme weather
label: media

text: The impact of climate change disproportionately affects the continent, resulting in severe floods , droughts and unprecedented heatwaves
label: media

text: In 2023 alone , about 15,700 people were killed in extreme weather disasters in Africa, and a further 34 million people affected
label: media

text: Storm Daniel caused widespread devastation in Libya , displacing 2
label: media

text: 4 million people
label: media

text: Kenya , Somalia and Ethiopia experienced intense rainfall and flooding
label: media

text: Northern Africa faced record-breaking heat, with temperatures reaching 49
label: media

text: 0°C in Tunisia and 50
label: media

text: 4°C in Algeria
label: media

text: Severe droughts hit Morocco, Algeria and Zambia, affecting millions
label: media

text: Prolonged droughts and crop failures make food shortages worse and mean that older people are unable to access healthy, nutritious food
label: media

text: Floods contribute to displacement and difficulties in accessing healthcare, resulting in stress and anxiety
label: media

text: Older people are also affected by the digital divide
label: media

text: Not having as much access to digital tools like smartphones means they cannot always get the information they need
label: media

text: They may not be able to see climate change education programmes, or get early warnings of extreme weather
label: media

text: Solutions Traditional knowledge: This is the understanding and practices that older people in Africa have gained over generations about their local environment
label: media

text: It includes knowing about climate patterns, resource use and disaster preparedness
label: media

text: Recognising this valuable knowledge can help communities adapt to climate change and strengthen local community resilience
label: media

text: Regular assessments: Local authorities and community organisations must monitor how older people are coping with climate impacts
label: media

text: This will lead to more effective adaptation strategies that make use of their insights
label: media

text: Healthy ageing: Older people need support to take care of their bodies, minds and social lives so that they can stay active and remain independent
label: media

text: Healthy ageing helps prevent illness and disabilities, and allows older adults to connect with communities and cope with extreme weather
label: media

text: One-stop shops for older people: These should be set up by community-based organisations, charities and government agencies to provide services such as financial assistance, healthcare and nutrition support specifically tailored for older people
label: media

text: They could also train older people to adapt to climate change
label: media

text: Involve older people in climate adaptation: Through their local organisations, older people should be involved in disaster risk reduction plans
label: media

text: Older people have already played vital roles in climate adaptation efforts across Africa
label: media

text: In Kenya, their mobilisation for national tree planting initiatives shows what a great contribution older people can make to the environment
label: media

text: A group of different generations also works together in Kenya on Agriculture for the Aged – planting climate-resilient crops to cope with unpredictable weather patterns
label: media

text: Policy changes needed For these solutions to become a reality, policies, and budgets are needed
label: media

text: First, policymakers should consult older people and their representatives when they draw up climate resilience strategies
label: media

text: Region-specific strategies are best
label: media

text: For example, when setting up community-based early warning systems for extreme weather events, local authorities could work with non-governmental organisations to create a system that provides timely alerts aimed at older people

text: Second, age-friendly infrastructure , such as accessible healthcare facilities and housing that can withstand extreme weather, must be set up
label: media

text: Read more: Why older people are some of those worst affected by climate change Third, stronger laws and political commitment will result in stronger policies for older people
label: media

text: The lack of political will often results in insufficient attention and resources being allocated to the needs of older people in climate action
label: media

text: Without strong commitment from policymakers, older populations are frequently overlooked
label: media

text: This limits their ability to adapt effectively
label: media

text: Fourth, social protection systems such as cash transfer programmes must be improved to give financial help to vulnerable older people

text: Programmes that provide direct support and jobs in projects that protect against climate impacts are also a good idea

text: To make this happen, governments and institutions must start collecting more data on how older people are affected by climate change

text: By developing inclusive policies, we can promote healthy ageing while empowering older adults to play an active role in building climate resilience

text: com/climate-change-health-risks-will-hit-the-poor-hardest-so-what-can-be-done-64929 Link copied Share article Discussions about climate change and the effects it will have on public health and the global burden of disease have been long in the making
label: media

text: These consequences are now starting to come to fore
label: media

text: Several examples have recently played out
label: media

text: For example, in Russia, an anthrax outbreak in the remote region of Siberia meant that nomadic communities and thousands of reindeer were affected
label: media

text: The outbreak was due to the bodies of infected people buried in 1941 defrosting and releasing anthrax spores into the water system as the permafrost defrosts with global warming
label: media

text: Closer to home, prisoners are starving in Malawian jails and suffering from acute severe malnutrition as a result of food shortages due to erratic climate conditions from both droughts and floods
label: media

text: Malawi has since declared a state of national disaster
label: media

text: These unanticipated public health consequences of unsustainable development reminds the world that the issues are not in the distant future, but instead face us now
label: media

text: Climate change exerts its influence on public health through three main mechanisms
label: media

text: First, the effects of extreme weather events such as heat, storms, floods or fire that directly cause loss of life or illness
label: media

text: Second, there are indirect effects of climate change on natural systems
label: media

text: This leads to, for example, changes in disease vectors such as mosquitoes that spread malaria, availability of fresh water, crop survival, or the concentration of pollen in the air
label: media

text: Third, the effects on economic and social systems as people migrate or conflict over scarce resources
label: media

text: These effects can be moderated by the presence of early warning systems and effective disaster and emergency medical services
label: media

text: More affluent communities with more resources will be better able to adapt and withstand these effects
label: media

text: Having strong primary healthcare systems will also increase the resilience of communities
label: media

text: But in sub-Saharan Africa many communities do not have these protective mechanisms in place, and will be particularly vulnerable to the impact of climate change
label: media

text: Electricity pylons in front of cooling towers at the Lethabo Thermal Power Station, an Eskom coal-burning power station near Sasolburg in the northern Free State province

text: /Siphiwe Sibeko Disease and environmental health The World Health Organisation has recently published a new report on the burden of disease due to modifiable environmental risks
label: media

text: The report estimates that 23% of all deaths globally can be attributed to environmental risks
label: media

text: This percentage rises to 26% in children
label: media

text: These environmental risks include: air, water and soil pollution; ultraviolet radiation; the built environment; the occupational environment; agricultural methods; and climate and ecosystem changes
label: media

text: Children, the elderly, and those living in low- and middle-income countries are most at risk
label: media

text: The diseases that make the greatest environmentally attributable contribution to the global burden of disease are stroke, ischaemic heart disease, diarrhoea, lower respiratory tract infection, cancers and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
label: media

text: And over the last ten years the contribution of non-communicable diseases has significantly increased
label: media

text: An example in South Africa is from Mpumalanga’s Highveld, which has 12 coal fired power stations
label: media

text: The collective air pollution from these power stations has been reported as being responsible for just over half of the deaths from respiratory disease and cardiovascular disease in the area
label: media

text: Living differently Sustainable development has been defined as: … development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs
label: media

text: The United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals recognise that improving the wellbeing and health of people requires an approach that protects the planet from degradation
label: media

text: This is required because there are ecological limits to development that is based on ever-increasing consumption
label: media

text: But the climate crisis is just one of the manifestations of the world’s collective inability to live sustainably
label: media

text: There is also a loss of ecosystems and the biodiversity
label: media

text: This compromises the natural services they render to humanity: food, fresh water, clean air, building materials and even new medicines
label: media

text: Economic inequality is increasing
label: media

text: It is reported that 62 people now own as much wealth as 50% of the planet’s population
label: media

text: At the same time, we have seen unprecedented population growth and increasing urbanisation that is characterised by the growth of slums or informal settlements
label: media

text: The 21st-century challenge Humanity’s biggest challenge in the 21st century may be its ability to find a way of living sustainably and to tackle the crises of both planetary and public health
label: media

text: This will require action on a global scale by world leaders and by a change in collective consciousness
label: media

text: There are some encouraging signs
label: media

text: Brazil has joined China and the US in ratifying the Paris agreement on tackling climate change
label: media

text: China and the US are responsible for 38% of global emissions
label: media

text: World religious leaders have also joined forces to promote a change of consciousness as part of a “ season of creation ”
label: media

text: It can be summed up in the video message from Pope Francis, who says the relationship between poverty and the fragility of the planet requires another way of managing the economy and measuring progress, conceiving a new way of life
label: media

text: com/ghanas-health-system-isnt-quite-ready-for-climate-change-realities-122912 Link copied Share article Climate change has been labelled as the greatest public health risk of the 21st century
label: media

text: Health risks from climate change are expected to become increasingly severe in the coming years
label: media

text: They threaten the many advances being made in global public health
label: media

text: Several health risks are anticipated from climate change
label: media

text: These include increases of vector-borne and diarrhoeal diseases
label: media

text: There are also changes in the geographic range of infectious diseases
label: media

text: This means a spread into new regions, the emergence of new infectious diseases and reemergence of old ones
label: media

text: An increase in the intensity of infectious diseases in already endemic regions is also expected
label: media

text: Although climate change is a global threat, the potential risks are relatively higher in developing economies
label: media

text: These countries have overburdened and weak health systems, coupled with persistently poor health infrastructure
label: media

text: It’s anticipated that some of the worst effects of climate change will be felt in sub-Saharan Africa
label: media

text: For example, climatic change has been reported as a driving force for the malaria highland invasion in the East African highlands
label: media

text: It is crucial that countries’ public health systems are able to cope with climate sensitive diseases
label: media

text: The World Health Organisation (WHO) has acknowledged this and has outlined a range of mitigating measures
label: media

text: It identifies rebuilding public health capacity among the most important, cost-effective and urgent responses to climate change
label: media

text: This includes training in climate change and health to strengthen the technical and professional capacity of health personnel
label: media

text: Effective surveillance and emergency response systems also need to be put in place, coupled with sustainable prevention and control programmes
label: media

text: In addition, countries need to design national health adaptation strategies, implement programmes to mitigate the health eﬀects of climate change, and strengthen institutional capacities to address the health effects of climate change
label: media

text: I set out to study whether Ghana’s health system and health workers are prepared for the potential health risks linked to climate change
label: media

text: These risks include possible outbreaks of communicable diseases like meningococcal meningitis and cholera
label: media

text: The research The research focused on two districts located in different ecological zones
label: media

text: The areas, located in the southern and northern zones, were chosen to account for different perspectives
label: media

text: The focus of the research was on the capacity and preparedness towards climate related health emergencies as it relates to climate sensitive infectious diseases
label: media

text: Capacity and preparedness were assessed in two ways
label: media

text: First, I looked at whether programmes had been strengthened for professional health personnel to equip them to address potential climate related health risks
label: media

text: This could include human resource skill building and education
label: media

text: I also assessed the ability of health services to respond to potential emergencies from climate sensitive infectious diseases, emergency preparedness and management
label: media

text: In-depth interviews and surveys were carried out among health professionals within public health facilities located in the two districts
label: media

text: Potential climate change health emergency risks that relate to climate sensitive infectious diseases within the Ghanaian context were assessed in both districts
label: media

text: The questions related only to known health risks and diseases
label: media

text: The study showed that there were no capacity strengthening programmes for health workers to equip them to address potential climate related health risks
label: media

text: Over 80% of respondents from both study districts reported not receiving training or workshops targeted towards climate change and health
label: media

text: As a result, 65% of respondents in each district reported not having enough information to respond to climate related public health threats
label: media

text: Respondents gave contrasting views on the issue of emergency preparedness and management
label: media

text: Some said they were prepared to address potential climate health risks and emergencies
label: media

text: Others said they weren’t
label: media

text: Respondents who indicated unpreparedness bemoaned the challenges they faced in delivering even basic health services
label: media

text: They concluded that they were not ready to deal with the impact of climate change on local populations’ health
label: media

text: On the other hand, some respondents specified having the needed support, the necessary human resources and strategies in place to help address the health threats from climate change
label: media

text: The study also showed that the position of a health facility on the hierarchical structure affected its capacity and preparedness levels
label: media

text: Health workers interviewed within the higher level of health delivery (district hospitals) acknowledged some level of preparedness to deal with climate health emergencies compared to those at the lower level (health centres)
label: media

text: Both levels nevertheless declared they might have challenges in addressing climate change health emergencies
label: media

text: Overall, the study ﬁndings indicate that health systems capacity and preparedness levels towards climate change health risks didn’t diﬀer across the study contexts
label: media

text: Way forward Our study also shed light on the urgent need for reforms to combat the looming health impact of climate change
label: media

text: The findings call for vital measures to be put in place in terms of health systems adaptation planning and resilience building
label: media

text: It became apparent that knowledge, skill building, provision of logistics and infrastructure urgently need attention
label: media

text: There is also a need to provide more resources, especially at the local levels
label: media

text: In addition, health professionals require in-service training programmes on climate change and health needs
label: media

text: Training and education are key to improving preparedness and capacity
label: media

text: com/climate-change-is-making-it-harder-for-people-to-get-the-care-they-need-240557 Link copied Share article The world is witnessing the consequences of climate change: long-lasting changes in temperature and rainfall, and more intense and frequent extreme weather events such as heat waves, hurricanes, typhoons, flooding and drought
label: media

text: All make it harder for families and communities to meet their care needs
label: media

text: Climate change affects care systems in various ways
label: media

text: First, sudden illnesses and unexpected disabilities heighten the need for care
label: media

text: Second, it reduces access to important inputs for care such as water, food and safe shelter
label: media

text: Third, it can damage physical and social care infrastructures
label: media

text: It can also lead to breakdowns of traditional units of caregiving such as households and communities
label: media

text: And it creates new situations of need with the increase in displaced person settlements and refugee camps
label: media

text: Climate change creates sudden spikes in the demand for care, and serious challenges to meeting the growing need for care
label: media

text: All this has immediate and long lasting effects on human well-being
label: media

text: The size of the current unmet care needs throughout the world is substantial
label: media

text: In childcare alone, about 23% of children worldwide – nearly 350 million – need childcare but do not have it
label: media

text: Families in low- and lower-middle-income countries are the most in need
label: media

text: Similarly, as the world’s population ages rapidly, only a small proportion of the elderly who need assistance are able to use formal care (in an institution or paid homecare)
label: media

text: Most are cared for by family members or other unpaid caregivers
label: media

text: Much of this unpaid care and formal care work is provided by women and girls
label: media

text: Hundreds of millions of people around the world struggle to get healthcare
label: media

text: Expansion of access to essential health services has slowed compared to pre-2015
label: media

text: And healthcare costs still create financial hardship
label: media

text: Without comprehensive public and global support for care provision and the integration of care in the climate agenda, unmet care needs will only grow and inequalities will widen
label: media

text: Impact Climate change interacts with human health in complex ways
label: media

text: Its impact is highly uneven across populations
label: media

text: It depends on geographical region, income, education, gender roles, social norms, level of development, and the institutional capacity and accessibility of health systems
label: media

text: In 2018-22, Africa experienced the biggest increase in the heat-related mortality rate since 2000-05
label: media

text: This is not surprising as the continent has more frequent health-threatening temperatures than ever before and a growing population of people older than 65
label: media

text: Africa is also the region most affected by droughts in 2013-22, with 64% of its land area affected by at least one month of extreme drought per year on average
label: media

text: It was followed by Oceania (55% of its land area) and South and Central America (53%)
label: media

text: Scientific evidence also points to increases in health inequalities caused by climate change
label: media

text: The health effects of climate change are not uniformly felt by different population groups
label: media

text: Exposure, severity of impact, and ability of individuals to recover depend on a variety of factors
label: media

text: Physiological characteristics, income, education, type of occupation, location, social norms and health systems are some of them
label: media

text: For example, older people and young children face the greatest health risks from high temperatures
label: media

text: There is also evidence of the disproportionate effect of climate change on the health of people living in poverty and those who belong to disadvantaged groups
label: media

text: Women of lower social and economic status and with less education are more vulnerable to heat stress compared to women in wealthier households and with higher education or social status
label: media

text: They are exposed to pollution in the absence of clean cooking fuel, and to extreme heat as they walk to gather water and fuel, or do other work outdoors
label: media

text: Bad sanitation in poor urban areas increases the incidence of water-borne diseases after heavy rains and floods
label: media

text: Lack of access to healthcare services and the means to pay for medicines make it difficult for women and men in low-income households to recover from illness, heat strokes, and air pollution-related ailments
label: media

text: Mental health problems are being attributed to climate change as well
label: media

text: Studies show that the loss of family or kin member, home, livelihood and a safe environment can bring about direct emotional impacts
label: media

text: These adverse impacts increase the demand for caregiving and the care workload
label: media

text: Climate-induced health problems force family and community caregivers, particularly women, to spend more time looking after the sick and disabled, particularly frail elderly people and children
label: media

text: Effect on food and water Climate change threatens the availability of food, clean water and safe shelter
label: media

text: It erodes households’ and communities’ care capacity and hence societies’ ability to thrive
label: media

text: Fluctuations in food supply and rising food prices as a result of environmental disasters, along with the inadequacy of government policies, underscore the mounting challenge of meeting food needs
label: media

text: The threat of chronic shortage of safe drinking water has also risen
label: media

text: Water scarcity is an area where structural inequalities and gender disparities are laid bare
label: media

text: Care for the sick and disabled, the young and the elderly is compromised when water is scarce
label: media

text: Effects on providing care Extreme weather events disrupt physical care infrastructures
label: media

text: It may be hard to reach hospitals, clinics, daycare centres, nursery schools and nursing homes
label: media

text: Some facilities may be damaged and have to close
label: media

text: Another type of care system that can break down is family networks and support provided by friends and neighbours
label: media

text: These informal care sharing arrangements are illustrated in a study of the three large informal settlements in Nairobi
label: media

text: About half (50
label: media

text: 5%) of the sampled households reported having had a sick member in the two weeks before the survey
label: media

text: The majority relied on close friends and family members living nearby for care and support
label: media

text: Studies have shown that climate change eventually leads to livelihood loss and resource scarcity, which can weaken social cohesion and local safety nets in affected communities
label: media

text: Heightened risks and uncertainty and imminent changes in socio-economic and political conditions can also compel individuals or entire households to migrate
label: media

text: Migration is caused by a host of factors, but it has increasingly been a climate-related response
label: media

text: The World Bank’s Groundswell Report released in 2018 , for example, projected that climate change could force 216 million people to move within their countries by 2050 to avoid the slow-onset impacts of climate change
label: media

text: A possible consequence of migration is the withdrawal of care support provided by the migrating extended kin, neighbours or friends, increasing the caregiving load of people left behind
label: media

text: In the case of forced displacements, the traditional social networks existing in communities are disrupted entirely
label: media

text: What’s needed There are compelling reasons to believe that meeting care needs can also help mitigate the effects of climate change
label: media

text: And actions to meet carbon-zero goals, prevent biodiversity loss and regenerate ecosystems can reduce the care work burden that falls heavily on families, communities and women
label: media

text: Any effort to tackle these grave problems should be comprehensive in scope and must be based on principles of equality, universality, and responsibility shared by all
label: media

text: This article is part of a series of articles initiated through a project led by the Southern Centre for Inequality studies, in collaboration with the International Development Research Centre and a group of feminist economists and climate scientists across the world
label: media

text: com/climate-change-will-widen-the-social-and-health-gap-30105 Link copied Share article Climate projections suggest that, thanks to human activity, we will likely see an increase in extreme weather events, disruptions to agriculture, loss of livelihoods and displacement of people
label: media

text: While everyone will be affected, these climate impacts will exacerbate social and health inequities, depending on underlying economic, geographic, social and health status
label: media

text: Recently there’s been increasing attention on climate change and health, including calls from Australian scientists , led by Professor Peter Doherty, for the government to put climate change on the G20 agenda
label: media

text: My research focuses on social inequality, and how that might exacerbate climate changes impact on health inequalities, including vulnerability to extreme weather and rising food prices
label: media

text: I presented some of the latest research on this topic at a recent Australian Academy of Science symposium on climate and health
label: media

text: Inequities of man-made natural disasters Low-lying cities and towns near coasts are facing increased risks from more frequent and more intense cyclones
label: media

text: These storms can generate storm surges causing flooding, direct injury and damage to infrastructure, including housing, water and sanitation systems
label: media

text: Poorer households are usually at higher direct health risk due to weaker structures, less safe locations and building sites, and the weaker resilience of infrastructure in poorer cities and towns to withstand damage
label: media

text: At the end of 2013, the Philippines were hit by devastating super typhoon Haiyan, which affected 16 million people
label: media

text: 6,069 people were reported dead while 4
label: media

text: 1 million people were displaced, with 1
label: media

text: 1 million houses damaged or destroyed
label: media

text: While everyone was touched by the typhoon, large income inequalities meant that poorer people not only lived in poorer quality housing, they were also more likely to be living on cheaper land in vulnerable low-lying regions
label: media

text: Poorer households also often lack the economic resources to evacuate in the face of climate-related disasters, or to rebuild
label: media

text: The ﬂooding of New Orleans in 2005 gave a striking example of what can happen among socially disadvantaged communities
label: media

text: Elderly patients in homes and poor people could not evacuate in front of the storm because of lack of transport
label: media

text: We see similar issues with heatwaves
label: media

text: Lower socioeconomic and minority ethnic groups are more likely to live and work in warmer neighbourhoods and in buildings that are poorly ventilated and absorb heat
label: media

text: This increases the risk of heat stress and heat deaths
label: media

text: Poor neighbourhoods with weak infrastructure, buildings and unplanned developments with little green spaces are likely to be more exposed to high temperatures compared to more affluent neighbourhoods
label: media

text: Impacts on agriculture Our agricultural systems are also under threat
label: media

text: Increasing drought periods in Australia may challenge the viability of agriculture in some regions, and hence those communities that depend on primary production
label: media

text: This will affect people’s income, stress levels and sense of hope
label: media

text: In 2003 bushfires ravaged eastern Victoria, destroying more than 40 homes and killing thousands of cattle
label: media

text: But the bushfires exacerbated problems already present in the community, typical of other rural Australian communities
label: media

text: Economic and climate pressures on rural farming communities has created financial hardship, led to closures in local businesses, and young people moving away
label: media

text: This has transformed the social landscape and support that is often present within rural communities
label: media

text: These factors we know have real implications for mental health and may increase risk of suicidal thoughts
label: media

text: Climate change also exacerbates food insecurity
label: media

text: Modelling estimates suggest that between 2005 and 2007 there was a 33% increase in the price of vegetables and a 43% increase in fruit prices in Australia because of the drought and extreme weather events
label: media

text: Rising food prices most affect the poor — as a proportion of total household expenditure, food makes up an average of around 19%
label: media

text: But, with 12% of Australians living below the poverty line, these average figures hide some of the food security difficulties many Australians face
label: media

text: Climate pressures will widen the food gap between those able to maintain a healthy diet of fresh produce, fish, lean meat and so on, and those needing to find the cheapest sources of calories
label: media

text: Cheap calories are found in the most highly processed, long shelf-life products, containing hardened fats and bulk starches, preserved with sugar or salt
label: media

text: Where does inequality come from
label: media

text: Climate change throws into sharp relief many of the issues to do with inequities in living standards, resource use, levels of exposure to environmental stresses, and existing health inequities
label: media

text: Australians who are more socially disadvantaged (by income, employment status, education) and Indigenous Australians are more likely to die younger and have a higher risk of depression, diabetes, heart disease and cancers
label: media

text: Parts of our cities are marked by concentrations of long term unemployment, low levels of education, and poor and dangerous housing conditions, leading to poor physical and mental health outcomes
label: media

text: The health experience of people living in rural and remote Australia is often worse than the urban average
label: media

text: Climate change itself is a product of the same forces that have created inequality in different groups of people
label: media

text: In creating a global marketplace that depends upon ever-increasing volumes of production and consumption, the economic and social trajectory of the 20th century and beyond has led to increasing over-exploitation of finite natural resources and to overloading natural environmental systems
label: media

text: The best way to address the unequal effects of climate change is address the causes of climate change and inequality
label: media

text: This might include : fairer and more sustainable food systems; affordable quality housing; pensions and benefits set no lower than the poverty line and indexed to average wages; and the establishment of more quality job creation programs in priority areas
label: media

text: This will not only improve health, but advances will be made in social equity such that communities and nations will be better able to resist current climate change and avert further damage to the environment
label: media
